titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the I. Babel' letters
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Lora Soroka

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-09-22T16:55-0700
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

did.abstract: Letters to family members relating to Russian literature and personal affairs. Includes typed transcripts. Photocopy.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], I. Babel' letters, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 2006.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Isaak Babel', Russian/Soviet writer, was born in 1894, in Odessa. In 1915 he moved to Petrograd, where he met Maksim Gorky, who became his friend and mentor. He published Babel's two short stories in the Letopis' magazine. Gorky advised the aspiring writer to gain more life experience. According to one of Babel's stories, Doroga (The Road), he served on the Romanian front until early December 1917. He resurfaced in Petrograd in March 1918 as a reporter for Gorky's newspaper, Novaya zhizn (New Life). During the Russian Civil War, Babel' worked for the publishing house of the Odessa Gubkom (regional CPSU Committee), in the food procurement unit in the Narkompros (People's Commissariat of Education), and in a typographic printing office.
After the end of the Civil War, Babel' worked as a reporter for Zaria Vostoka (The Dawn of the Orient).
Babel' married Yevgenia Gronfein on August 9, 1919, in Odessa.

In 1920, Babel' was assigned to the First Cavalry Army and witnessed a military campaign in the Polish-Soviet War of 1920. He documented the horrors of that in the Konarmeiskiy Dnevnik, 1920 God (1920 Diary), which he later used to write Konarmiya (Red Cavalry), a collection of short stories.

In 1924, his mother and sister with her family immigrated to Belgium; in 1925 his wife immigrated to Paris. Babel' visited them several times during his trips to France; in 1929, his daughter Natalie was born. Babel' wrote letters to his family from 1925 through 1939, when he was arrested and put in prison.

Babel' was arrested in May 1939; his writings were confiscated and disappeared. He was tortured during interrogations. In January 1940 he was executed, and his name disappeared from literary life: it was removed from literary dictionaries and encyclopedias and taken off school and university syllabi. He was rehabilitated in 1954.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Letters relating to Russian literature and personal affairs from Babel' to his family members: mother, Fania Babel'; sister, Mera Chapochnikoff, and her husband Grigorii; and Babel's wife and daughter. Includes typed transcripts. Photocopy.
It should be noted that some original letters do not have corresponding transcripts, while some transcripts were made from letters unavailable in this collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes two letters of November 5, 1925.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Three letters to Babel's mother and one letter to his sister; one letter without beginning; and one letter from Babel's mother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unfinished letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Page 2 only.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a letter to sister of April 5, 1926 (two copies), and a letter to mother of April 16, 1926, containing an undated letter from Babel's mother (two copies).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes two letters of September 17, 1926.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes two letters of November 2, 1926 (to mother and sister), and a letter of November 10, 1926, and one loose page (beginning is missing).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from Fania Aronovna (Babel's mother) to Mera (Babel's sister).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The postcard of February 23, 1929, was copied next to the postcard of July 20, 1929. See Box 1, Folder 6.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The postcard of September 25, 1930, was copied next to the postcard of December 15, 1930.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Additional copy of the January 2 postcard can be found next to the postcard of February 25, 1931. The postcard of January 27, 1931, was copied next to the postcard of April 19, 1931.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The postcard of April 24, 1931, was copied next to the postcard of July 15, 1931. See Box 1, Folder 9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes two postcards of June 20, 1931, and a letter and a postcard of June 26, 1931. The postcard of June 29, 1931, was copied next to the postcard of July 9, 1931. See Box 1, Folder 9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The postcard of July 2, 1931, was copied next to the postcard of October 21, 1931; the postcard of July 22, 1931, was copied next to the postcard of October 6, 1931. Includes two postcards of July 31, 1931.
